description: Past tense for completed actions with -ar verbs: -é, -aste, -ó, -amos, -asteis, -aron. Used for specific past events with a defined beginning and/or end.
common_errors: Forgetting the accent on yo (-é) and él/ella (-ó) forms
Confusing with imperfect tense
practice_patterns: Ella ___ (comprar) un libro la semana pasada.
Nosotros ___ (viajar) a Barcelona el verano pasado.

description: Past tense for completed actions with -er/-ir verbs: -í, -iste, -ió, -imos, -isteis, -ieron. Note: -er and -ir verbs share the same preterite endings.
common_errors: Forgetting accents on -í and -ió
Mixing up -er/-ir preterite with -ar preterite endings

description: Key irregular preterites: ir/ser (fui, fuiste, fue, fuimos, fuisteis, fueron), hacer (hice, hiciste, hizo...), tener (tuve...), estar (estuve...), poder (pude...), poner (puse...), decir (dije...), venir (vine...).
common_errors: Ir and ser share the same preterite forms (context distinguishes them)
Applying regular endings to irregular stems
Hizo not hico (c->z spelling change)

description: Imperfect for habitual past actions and descriptions: -ar verbs: -aba, -abas, -aba, -ábamos, -abais, -aban. -er/-ir verbs: -ía, -ías, -ía, -íamos, -íais, -ían. Used for 'used to' and 'was doing'.
common_errors: Confusing when to use imperfect vs preterite
Forgetting accent on -ábamos and all -ía forms

concept: Imperfect tense - irregular verbs (ser, ir, ver)
description: Only three verbs are irregular in the imperfect: ser (era, eras, era, éramos, erais, eran), ir (iba, ibas, iba, íbamos, ibais, iban), ver (veía, veías, veía, veíamos, veíais, veían).
common_errors: Forgetting that these are the ONLY irregular imperfect verbs
Confusing 'era' (imperfect ser) with 'fue' (preterite ser)
practice_patterns: Cuando yo ___ (ser) joven, ___ (ir) a la playa.

description: Preterite: completed actions, specific time, sequence of events. Imperfect: habitual actions, descriptions, ongoing background, age/time/weather. Often combined: imperfect sets the scene, preterite interrupts.
common_errors: Using preterite for descriptions ('era alto' not 'fue alto' for describing someone)
Using imperfect for completed sequences

description: Reflexive pronouns: me, te, se, nos, os, se. Placed before conjugated verb or attached to infinitive/gerund. Many daily routine verbs are reflexive: levantarse, acostarse, ducharse, vestirse, lavarse.
common_errors: Forgetting the reflexive pronoun
Wrong pronoun-subject agreement
Placement with compound tenses

description: Direct object pronouns replace the thing/person receiving the action: me, te, lo/la, nos, os, los/las. Placed before conjugated verb or attached to infinitive/gerund/affirmative command.
common_errors: Wrong gender agreement (lo vs la)
Placing pronoun after conjugated verb
Forgetting personal 'a' with people

description: Indirect object pronouns indicate to/for whom: me, te, le, nos, os, les. Often used with verbs of giving, telling, showing. Redundant use with 'a + person' is common and correct in Spanish.
common_errors: Confusing direct and indirect objects
Forgetting redundant 'le' with 'a + person'
Le/les don't change for gender
practice_patterns: Yo ___ doy el libro a María. (le/les)

description: Comparatives: más/menos + adjective + que. Equality: tan + adjective + como. Superlatives: el/la más + adjective + de. Irregular: mejor (better), peor (worse), mayor (older), menor (younger).
common_errors: Using 'más bueno' instead of 'mejor'
Using 'más malo' instead of 'peor'
Confusing 'que' and 'de' in superlatives
practice_patterns: Este libro es ___ ___ de todos. (el mejor)
Mi casa es tan grande ___ la tuya. (como)

description: Three levels of distance: este/esta/estos/estas (this/these, near speaker), ese/esa/esos/esas (that/those, near listener), aquel/aquella/aquellos/aquellas (that/those, far from both). Neuter forms: esto, eso, aquello.
common_errors: Confusing ese and aquel (distance from speaker matters)
Forgetting gender/number agreement
Using neuter forms with known nouns
practice_patterns: ___ casa es de María. (that - near you)

description: Para: purpose/goal (para estudiar), recipient (para ti), destination (para Madrid), deadline (para mañana). Por: cause/reason (por eso), duration (por dos horas), exchange (por diez euros), movement through (por el parque), means (por email).
common_errors: Using para for duration (should be por)
Using por for destination (should be para)
Confusing cause (por) with purpose (para)

description: Key prepositions: en (in/on/at), a (to), de (from/of), entre (between), sobre (on top of/about), debajo de (under), delante de (in front of), detrás de (behind), al lado de (next to), cerca de (near), lejos de (far from).
common_errors: Confusing en and a (en = location, a = direction/destination)
Forgetting 'de' in compound prepositions: debajo de, delante de
practice_patterns: El gato está ___ la mesa. (debajo de/encima de)
Mi casa está ___ el parque. (cerca de/lejos de)

description: Informal commands for tu: regular forms match the third person singular present tense (habla, come, escribe). Common irregulars: di (decir), haz (hacer), ve (ir), pon (poner), sal (salir), sé (ser), ten (tener), ven (venir).
common_errors: Using infinitive as command ('hablar' instead of 'habla')
Forgetting irregular forms
Confusing with usted commands

description: Formal commands for usted: take the yo present form, drop -o, add opposite ending (-ar verbs: -e, -er/-ir verbs: -a). Hablo -> hable, como -> coma, escribo -> escriba. Irregulars follow the same pattern from irregular yo forms.
common_errors: Forgetting to switch the vowel ending
Not starting from the yo form for irregulars

description: Negative commands use subjunctive forms for ALL persons. No + subjunctive form. Tu: no hables, no comas, no escribas. Usted: no hable, no coma, no escriba. Pronoun placement: before the verb in negatives.
common_errors: Using affirmative tu form with no ('no habla' instead of 'no hables')
Attaching pronouns to negative commands (should precede the verb)

description: Haber (present) + past participle: he, has, ha, hemos, habéis, han + -ado (ar verbs) / -ido (er/ir verbs). Used for recent past or past with present relevance. Irregular participles: hecho, dicho, escrito, visto, puesto, vuelto, abierto, roto.
common_errors: Separating haber from the participle
Using ser/estar instead of haber as auxiliary
Forgetting irregular past participles

description: Frequency: siempre (always), casi siempre (almost always), a menudo/frecuentemente (often), a veces (sometimes), casi nunca (hardly ever), nunca/jamás (never). Time: ya (already), todavía/aún (still/yet), ahora (now), después (after), antes (before).
common_errors: Position of adverbs (usually before verb or at sentence start/end)
Double negative with nunca: 'No voy nunca' = 'Nunca voy'

description: Coordinating: y/e (and), o/u (or), pero (but), sino (but rather), ni...ni (neither...nor). Causal: porque (because), como (since). Purpose: para que (so that). Temporal: cuando (when), mientras (while), antes de (before), después de (after).
common_errors: Y changes to 'e' before words starting with i-/hi-
O changes to 'u' before words starting with o-/ho-
Confusing pero and sino
practice_patterns: Iré al cine ___ termine el trabajo. (cuando/mientras)

description: Que is the most common relative pronoun in Spanish, meaning 'that/which/who'. It can refer to people or things. Used to join two sentences: El libro que compré es interesante. La chica que vive aquí es simpática.
common_errors: Omitting 'que' as English often omits 'that'
Using quien when que is sufficient for defining clauses
practice_patterns: La mujer ___ trabaja aquí es mi madre.
Los estudiantes ___ estudian mucho aprenden rápido.

description: Weather uses hacer: hace calor/frío/sol/viento/buen tiempo/mal tiempo. Also: llueve (it rains), nieva (it snows), está nublado (it's cloudy). Impersonal expressions: hay que + infinitive (one must), se puede (one can), es necesario/importante/posible.
common_errors: Using ser/estar for weather instead of hacer
Confusing hay (there is) with hace (weather)
Using hay que with conjugated verb instead of infinitive

description: Both mean 'to know'. Saber: facts, information, how to do something (saber + infinitive). Conocer: people, places, being familiar with. Saber: sé, sabes, sabe... Conocer: conozco, conoces, conoce... (irregular yo).
common_errors: Using saber for people ('sé a Juan' should be 'conozco a Juan')
Using conocer for facts ('conozco la respuesta' should be 'sé la respuesta')
practice_patterns: Yo ___ a María desde hace años. (sé/conozco)

description: Stem changes in all forms except nosotros/vosotros. e->ie: querer (quiero), pensar, empezar, preferir, sentir. o->ue: poder (puedo), dormir, volver, encontrar, contar. e->i: pedir (pido), servir, repetir, seguir.
common_errors: Applying stem change to nosotros/vosotros forms
Forgetting which vowel changes to which
Not recognizing stem-changing patterns

description: When the direct object is a specific person (or personified thing/pet), place 'a' before it. Veo a María. Llamo a mi madre. Not used with tener for possession: Tengo dos hermanos (no 'a'). Not used with indefinite people: Busco un médico.
common_errors: Omitting personal 'a' with specific people
Using personal 'a' with tener for possession
Using it with indefinite/non-specific people

concept: Hay vs estar for existence and location
description: Hay (there is/are): introduces existence of something new/indefinite. Está/están: locates something already known/definite. Hay un banco en la calle (existence). El banco está en la calle (location of known bank).
common_errors: Using hay with definite articles ('hay el libro' should be 'el libro está')
Using estar to introduce something new
